reviewText:
Playing video games for the first time long after their release is not always a bad thing. Indeed it enables us to see how they endure the test of time. And only true jewels can stand it. What about Bioshock II ? As I had been blown away after playing the first opus, I expected a lot from this sequel. And so did many Bioshock fans. Here's my review :

(See rating at the end of the review)

____________________________

GAMEPLAY: Quite similar to what we experienced in the first game. The gameplay is really focused on immersive and explosive fighting sequences. The difference with the first opus is that there's no real final boss but very often the player is opposing big waves of ennemies. Hopefully it is possible to prepare your defense by setting traps and mines, hacking security cameras and turrets. But if you want to collect all the Adam, these defensive fights become too repetitive. On a more positive note, some new weapons add more fun to the gameplay. I really enjoyed playing with the drill and the spear gun. Moreover, it's really interesting to combine different weapon's and plasmid's attacks. I liked the fact, that as a Big Daddy you really feel the strength and the weight of your character. There are also different levels of difficulty that you may choose depending on your experience in FPS games. So don't worry if you're not used to this type of game. I'm not, but I still truly enjoyed playing it.

VISUALS, MUSIC & ATMOSPHERE: That's why so many people love the Bioshock saga : a deep immersion into an equally beautiful and horrific world. Of course, I already knew how Rapture looked like but I was still surprised by the beauty of the scenery. And even if the game engine is getting older, the esthetic of this chaotic city is still mind-blowing. The new developers have even got further with more cutscenes and submarine exploration that offers quiet and contemplative moments between the fighting sequences. I also have to praise the soundtrack, the voice-acting and the sound effects that are even better than in the first Bioshock.

STORY: In this sequel, which occurs ten years after the events of the first game, we play in this sequel a reborn Big Daddy who's trying to get back to his little sister. Our quest offers us the possibility to explore many new places and to meet new cheracters. The most interesting ones are the utopist Sofia Lamb and the opportunist Sinclair who take the roles of Ryan and Atlas in the antagonist-protagonist pattern. Because we are more familiar with Rapture and it's doom, we are less surprised by the wickedness of its inhabitants but there are still some strong revelations. Many elements of the story are smartly scattered in the Audio Diaries that the player finds on its way. And as we move towards the end of the game, the story becomes more and more intense. To me, three of the four different endings are a bit overdramatic but they still have a great theatrical effect.

LENGTH: It takes around 10 hours to finish the game. More than that if you don't use the quest arrow. There's four different endings that you can experience depending of your choices, but because the game is very scripted I wouldn't do it all over again.

reviewText:
I came worried that Rapture would lose its magic second time around, and left realizing how much of a fool I was. The city is more amazing than it was in the first game, characters better fleshed out, story more focused and generally everything feels significantly improved. While during the first game I spent the first hours just understanding what the hell the setting was about, this time Rapture felt like bleak home and I could appreciate everything from the beginning without that slow learning curve. Obviously, much of the mystery is diminished since it's not the first time. But you're compensated with better mechanics, stunning environments and a deeper story.

Tonics and Plasmids are still a great joy, improving the FPS with light RPG elements of character customization. The variety of active and passive abilities allows you to choose between an impressive range of playstyles. Sneak? Melee? Guns ablazing? Setting traps? Hypnotizing enemies to fight by your side? Use machines to wreak havoc? You name it, you have it. Combined with an unparalled atmosphere and unique setting, using the foundations of the first masterpiece and building upon them, BioShock is 20-some hours of pure fun of the best kind in computer games.

I recommend playing the first before the second. Otherwise, you'll have a hard time enjoying the most of the plot. You'll miss out on a lot of characters and spend too long trying to fill in the gaps by what you understand from the events. And this is a game you want to delve into the plot. If just for Rapture, its history and its imaginative premise.

reviewText:
Playing video games for the first time long after their release is not always a bad thing. Indeed it enables us to see how they endure the test of time. And only true jewels can stand it. What about Bioshock II ? As I had been blown away after playing the first opus, I expected a lot from this sequel. And so did many Bioshock fans. Here's my review :

(See rating at the end of the review)

____________________________

GAMEPLAY: Quite similar to what we experienced in the first game. The gameplay is really focused on immersive and explosive fighting sequences. The difference with the first opus is that there's no real final boss but very often the player is opposing big waves of ennemies. Hopefully it is possible to prepare your defense by setting traps and mines, hacking security cameras and turrets. But if you want to collect all the Adam, these defensive fights become too repetitive. On a more positive note, some new weapons add more fun to the gameplay. I really enjoyed playing with the drill and the spear gun. Moreover, it's really interesting to combine different weapon's and plasmid's attacks. I liked the fact, that as a Big Daddy you really feel the strength and the weight of your character. There are also different levels of difficulty that you may choose depending on your experience in FPS games. So don't worry if you're not used to this type of game. I'm not, but I still truly enjoyed playing it.

VISUALS, MUSIC & ATMOSPHERE: That's why so many people love the Bioshock saga : a deep immersion into an equally beautiful and horrific world. Of course, I already knew how Rapture looked like but I was still surprised by the beauty of the scenery. And even if the game engine is getting older, the esthetic of this chaotic city is still mind-blowing. The new developers have even got further with more cutscenes and submarine exploration that offers quiet and contemplative moments between the fighting sequences. I also have to praise the soundtrack, the voice-acting and the sound effects that are even better than in the first Bioshock.

STORY: In this sequel, which occurs ten years after the events of the first game, we play in this sequel a reborn Big Daddy who's trying to get back to his little sister. Our quest offers us the possibility to explore many new places and to meet new cheracters. The most interesting ones are the utopist Sofia Lamb and the opportunist Sinclair who take the roles of Ryan and Atlas in the antagonist-protagonist pattern. Because we are more familiar with Rapture and it's doom, we are less surprised by the wickedness of its inhabitants but there are still some strong revelations. Many elements of the story are smartly scattered in the Audio Diaries that the player finds on its way. And as we move towards the end of the game, the story becomes more and more intense. To me, three of the four different endings are a bit overdramatic but they still have a great theatrical effect.

LENGTH: It takes around 10 hours to finish the game. More than that if you don't use the quest arrow. There's four different endings that you can experience depending of your choices, but because the game is very scripted I wouldn't do it all over again.

reviewText:
Love it! The story is amazing, graphics are good ('specially compared to the first Bioshock!), controls and combat are pristine.

Multiplayer is still somewhat alive! There seems to be quite a few people who play every day, and there are times of day when you'll get to try it out; around 6pm or later. It was always my favorite FPS multiplayer, but the xbox Bioshock 2 community died out a long time ago so it's nice to see people still play it on the PC. What's cool about the pvp is that you can type to people while you kill 'em, so there's a good, nice, hopeful community playing the game, we hope the community grows but it's definitely an older game. I've been playing multiplayer every day for the past week or so, and I rarely have to sit and wait for a game.

The PvP is awesome. Out of all the shooters I've played, it's my favorite. Everyone has a pretty good amount of health so it's not just 1shot vs 1shot hiding around a corner camping; it's different. I mean, there's still 1shot combos and stuff but not everyone has perfected that so it's pretty fair. Wielding plasmids and shooting lightning bolts and crossbows, and turning invisible are the coolest things ever.

It was difficult to set the controls for an Xbox controller, if anyone has any questions (how to edit the sensitivity of an xbox controller for multiplayer) just message me.

Edit: the PvP community isn't as good as I thought lmao, I keep trying to play; I try once every few weeks, but everyone's adopted the Grenade Launcher strategy; it's a 1shot kill basically, it's overpowered and everyone kind of hates it. I haven't been able to progress much in PvP. I really miss the old xbox days when there were a lot of people playing every day. Now all I see are the same people using the same 1shot strategies over and over. Stun + crossbow = instant 1shot. grenade launcher = stun/disorient/1shot/range, and if you suicide yourself with the grenade launcher, the other team doesn't get a kill, and there's no penalty. You can stand outside a room and fling grenades into the room and get multiple kills without even aiming or trying. That's what PvP is right now basically, I wish there was a game mode that doubled the health of players, just so it isn't 1shots, but requires slightly more strategy than Electro Bolt / Crossbow, which barely requires aiming skill

reviewText:
Love it! The story is amazing, graphics are good ('specially compared to the first Bioshock!), controls and combat are pristine.

Multiplayer is still somewhat alive! There seems to be quite a few people who play every day, and there are times of day when you'll get to try it out; around 6pm or later. It was always my favorite FPS multiplayer, but the xbox Bioshock 2 community died out a long time ago so it's nice to see people still play it on the PC. What's cool about the pvp is that you can type to people while you kill 'em, so there's a good, nice, hopeful community playing the game, we hope the community grows but it's definitely an older game. I've been playing multiplayer every day for the past week or so, and I rarely have to sit and wait for a game.

The PvP is awesome. Out of all the shooters I've played, it's my favorite. Everyone has a pretty good amount of health so it's not just 1shot vs 1shot hiding around a corner camping; it's different. I mean, there's still 1shot combos and stuff but not everyone has perfected that so it's pretty fair. Wielding plasmids and shooting lightning bolts and crossbows, and turning invisible are the coolest things ever.

It was difficult to set the controls for an Xbox controller, if anyone has any questions (how to edit the sensitivity of an xbox controller for multiplayer) just message me.

Edit: the PvP community isn't as good as I thought lmao, I keep trying to play; I try once every few weeks, but everyone's adopted the Grenade Launcher strategy; it's a 1shot kill basically, it's overpowered and everyone kind of hates it. I haven't been able to progress much in PvP. I really miss the old xbox days when there were a lot of people playing every day. Now all I see are the same people using the same 1shot strategies over and over. Stun + crossbow = instant 1shot. grenade launcher = stun/disorient/1shot/range, and if you suicide yourself with the grenade launcher, the other team doesn't get a kill, and there's no penalty. You can stand outside a room and fling grenades into the room and get multiple kills without even aiming or trying. That's what PvP is right now basically, I wish there was a game mode that doubled the health of players, just so it isn't 1shots, but requires slightly more strategy than Electro Bolt / Crossbow, which barely requires aiming skill

reviewText:
I just finished this game at the time of writing and wow am I impressed. I have heard from a lot of people that this is their least favorite of the franchise, but I would honestly say it is probably my favorite. It combines all the good gameplay elements from the other two games and adds a little extra strategy with the Little Sisters and such. I don't know, it felt much more action packed than the first one because you could dual wield plasmids and guns, but it also felt more strategic unlike Infinite wear you can only carry two guns at a time and from what I remember, no ammo differences. Plus there aren't gene tonics to customize your character in Infinite. Anyway, I thought this was a marvellous game. I love the Rapture setting and the quality game mechanics. The story was good and felt a lot more emotional than the first one. I have yet to play Minerva's Den or the online mode(both of which I plan to get to).

Pros:
Good visuals
Exciting fun gameplay
Strategic shooter
Heartfelt story
Well optimized

Cons:
Scrolling through weapons goes the wrong way when you use your mouse wheel. Ended up using number buttons
Having Big Daddy mask was obnoxious, but you can turn that off
Wish it would auto-save a bit more often

Overall, I'd give this game a perfect 10/10. I'm honest, it is one of the best games I have ever played. A 10/10 is saying a lot from me. I would HIGHLY suggest it to anyone remotely interested in a FPS game to play through. It is totally worth the $20 and you can even often get it for less.

reviewText:
My favorite game out've the entire Bioshock series.

The game's story is as solid as the first, and the gameplay mechanics have been further improved (such as the ability to dual wield a plasmid and a weapon all at once).

Another great thing about Bioshock 2 is the fact that it has a multiplayer portion of the game which is equally as enthralling, something that Infinite lacked (disappointingly).

In all honesty, I can be a bit biased about Bioshock games because they hold a special place in my heart. It's one of the only games I can replay the Single-Player portion over and over.

All in all, for a combination of story, gameplay and the graphics for its time, i'd give the game a 9/10.

reviewText:
Bioshock 2 stays relatively similar to Bioshock 1 in the playstyle, environment (Rapture), enemies, and plasmids while bringing in quite a few cool new elements. First of all, in Bioshock 2, you play as a Big Daddy. I'm not going to say too much more about the story as it would lead to spoilers, but the story is quite compelling to follow. In terms of pure enjoyment, Bioshock 2 was just slightly less enjoyable than Bioshock 1 because being a Big Daddy was kind of annoying when you hear a grunting noise every few seconds and when you jump and land.

My one problem with Bioshock 2 was that it started crashing a lot as I got further and further into the game. I got into the habit of quicksaving every minute or so in order to not lose progress so it was still bearable. But aside from the crashing, Bioshock 2 is a VERY fun game to play and is just and incredible continuation of Bioshock 1 in another area of Rapture. I know this review is pretty disorganized and jumbled, but if you are to take anything out of this, Bioshock 2 is worth playing.

Rating: 9.1/10
Recommend Price: Any Price because it is that good

reviewText:
Bioshock 2 retains most of the elements of the first game adding the ability to combine certain plasmids to create traps and the Big Sisters.
Gameplay wise, the game is nearly identical to the first one however, the story is more developed this time.
The game continues employing a great atmosphere with audio and detailed backgrounds as well a good looking lightning effects.
Voice acting is great and makes the story believable. The writing has been with such quality that you will grow interested in the story and in the characters that you meet during your travel.

While the game's online functionality is non existant nowadays, Bioshock 2 is a game in which the story mode takes the center stage.
If you enjoy games with great storytelling and atmosphere, Bioshock 2 is a game you shouldn't miss.

reviewText:
TLDR: An enjoyable follow-up to the first game continues the story of Rapture with a new protagonist, a new conflicted (kind of) big boss and more gene splicing action. This time around you have some moral decision making to do, and your actions affect the game’s ending.

If you’ve played the first Bioshock game, you’ll remember that in the mid 1900’s the world’s top minds secretly worked together to build the underwater city of Rapture, and created what they thought was the ultimate utopia, free of government and religion. Instead they were ruled by the free market and meritocracy, so everyone makes money based on being good at something. In Bioshock 2, you learn that the pressures of this “perfect world” started to get to the citizens (especially the poor), and a psychiatrist was brought in to help people deal with the stresses of pure competition. Unfortunately, the psychiatrist Sofia Lamb had her own agenda, and saw the opportunity to create a true Utopia in Rapture through the use of Adam.

Adam is a genetic material that can be used to create “plasmids” for artificial evolution through gene splicing. It doesn’t just give people super powers though, apparently it can be used to transfer the memories of the users to certain prepared users (Little Sisters). Little Sisters are orphaned girls who have been kidnapped and turned into walking “Adam factories” who can later be harvested for their gooey Adam. The Little Sisters are guarded by Big Daddies, brainwashed people in armored diving gear who are psychically linked to their Little Sisters and guard them from any threat.

In Bioshock 2, you play a Big Daddy, though the gameplay is nearly the same as in the first game (where you were a human). It’s still a First Person Shooter and the weapons are mostly the same as well. There’s been a refinement to the plasmid system where you’re basically dual wielding now (plasmid in one hand and gun in the other). In the first game you had to switch between gun and plasmid. A big change is that because you’re a Big Daddy, you do a bunch of mini escort missions where you guard Little Sisters as they gather their Adam. Just like in the first game, you have a huge variety of weapon ammo types and plasmid types to help you survive, though you might notice that the game is more difficult this time around. It seems like you take more damage in Bioshock 2 than in the first game.

Pros:
+The story is good though it’s a little difficult to figure out what the deal is with Sofia Lamb. How did she turn into such a ♥♥♥♥♥?
+The game takes what is good about the first game and adds to it. I kind of liked the hacking mini game in the first game better though. There are more weapon types, more plasmids, and more enemies. The mini bosses in the first game were the Big Daddies, who are back, but now you have the Big Sisters to deal with as well and they’re twice as powerful.
+The game has 6 different endings depending on the moral choices you make throughout, but they’re actually very close to each other. I’ve probably only seen 3 of them because I usually play games as a “good person” and had to go out of my way to make evil decisions.

Cons:
-People have told me that Bioshock 2 is the weakest in the Bioshock series and I can see their point. There really isn’t much more innovation and it’s kind of like a continuation of the first game in terms of technical improvement. Like with Saints Row 4, where people said it was almost a really long DLC for Saints Row 3.
-There were some technical issues for me related to graphics. It seems to be a common occurrence based on what I found when googling for solutions. To keep the game from crashing, I had to change the display to Direct X 9.

Overall, if you liked the first Bioshock, you’ll probably like Bioshock 2, though maybe not quite as much. The game takes about 10 hours to beat and is more than worth your time.  8.5/10

reviewText: Welcome back to Rapture! This was a fun play. For those who have played Bioshock, this is a no brainer. You need to get it. Here are some things to keep in mind. There is not a lot of new groundbreaking material, which isn't necessarily a bad thing. When the first game got so many elements right, this game just transferred those elements to this game. Atmosphere, combat, and finding upgrades and shinies are just as fun and interesting as the first game. Plus, you get to be a Big Daddy. Thats just awesome. The only slight downer is the story. It is not a bad story at all, but it does not contain the massive twist that the first game had. Instead, the reveal in this game just answers questions you may have had during the game. There are a variety of endings depending on how merciful or cold-hearted you are. I enjoyed my trip back to Rapture and I know I will be making a few more trips.

reviewText:
This game takes some flak for not being as novel and unique as the first game, but realistically, that would have been impossible for a sequel. Instead it trades some novelty for an amazing thematic strength and even better gameplay than the first.

The biggest thing the Bioshock 2 developers deserve a lot of credit for is really investing themselves into the core concept of the game. The idea was that this time you are the Big Daddy. They could have just half-♥♥♥♥♥ the idea, and just made it Bioshock 1 with more clanking noises and a drill-arm. Instead they really went all-out with the concept. The game somewhat gently steers you into really behaving like a Big Daddy does from beginning to end, but in such a way that you may not really realize until you've already been doing it for three or four hours first.

It's pretty brilliantly done, at least I thought so. I've never seen a developer aim for a particular feeling from the gameplay itself and succeed so perfectly.

reviewText:
After playing the first two games in the BioShock series and starting the third, I can honestly say I like 2 more.

Gameplay and Customization: BioShock 2 managed to fix the clunkiness of its predecessor when it comes to shooting. It allows iron sights, which is awesome, and quick plasmid usage. The way this works it you have a weapon on your main hand and plasmid on your off hand at the same time. The variety of plasmids is also cool. The customization of BioShock games never cease to amaze me. Whether you want to be big badass Delta with a drill and offensive plasmids, or take a more subtle approach with the spear gun and stealthy plasmids, Bioshock 2 can provide such an experience.

Hacking and Research: This game decided to simplify hacking. Instead of having to play a puzzle minigame like in BioShock, you now need to land the hack needle on green or blue zones, green successfuly completeing hack while blue doing the same plus giving a free item. The Research system was overhauled. Instead of taking pictures of the target to gain research, now you have to video tape them. To get the best possible research, one must kill the target using a mixture of weapons, plasmids, npcs or security bots.

Story and Atmosphere:	 I don't understand why people don't like the story of BioShock 2. Though it doesnt follow Jacks life, which was clearly ended at the end of BioShock, its still pretty interesting.  The adventure of Delta and Sinclair on their way to save Eleanor was a great idea. They made sure to make you sad when you had to put down Sinclair. Also the endings are either sad of bad, there is no real happy one.  BioShock 2 does a great job in keeping the experience atmospheric, just like in the first game.

Overall:	 This game is better than the first one. If you like any of the above features, its a must have.
10/10 would take fall damage to see Delta make a mini earthquake.

reviewText:
So after a five day binge play of the BioShock franchise, here are my thoughts about the second installment. And though I'm going to recommend this title, I want to caveat the fact that it is by far, the worst in the franchise. It's well worth picking up on sale due to the fact that its story line reflects on the other two titles, but not worth it's asking price. Lets get into why....

I was warned by a friend that this game was sub par to the original BioShock, but at first blush I was confused as to why. It looked like a vast improvement, with brushed up graphics, new weapons, new enemies, and the ability to play as a Big Daddy. All things that should have made this a block buster game, but are handled so poorly that in the end it actually leaves you very disappointed.

Where to start..... The brushed up graphics at first seem to be a big improvement over the original. They fix one of my gripes about the first game with plenty of new Splicers, each with different voices and outfits, they even added new types of Big Daddy. The problem with this is that you eventually notice that what they've done is remove the glassy, 40s stylized look from the first game, and made everyone look more realistic". reviewText:
The ultimate anal-drilling-simulation leaves a bit of an aftertaste of ♥♥♥♥ in the players mouth, which might source from the fact that gameplay from the first game remains virtually unchanged, or that at heart, you drill splicers bumholes until they explode or you spend hours drilling a big daddy until he anticlimatically doesn't explode.
Bioshock 2 has great level design and an above average story (which contains more plotho
les than you can create bumdrilling splicers in the entire game) and continues the atmosphere of the first game in most aspects. If you are really into diving for  30 seconds max in between shootouts, you might really like this game too. Although it might not seem that way, the game has really good pacing and never have I felt bored playing the game, although it can be tiring to fight a big sister with as much health as a ♥♥♥♥ing level 90 tank in WoW. Most of that comes from the weaponry; as I previously mentioned, you get to shove your typical Big-Daddy-Drill into any splicers bumhole, and there are a couple really powerfully handled, awesome weapons to be found and upgraded. You feel actuallystrong in the game, not just like some flexed up Bodybuilder with double the ♥♥♥♥ that his mother possessed. But just like that particular roid-rage Arnold-Cutout, Bioshock 2 has one great weakness: The Glory of his predecessor. You can't top Arnold. He is just too glorious.

Would I recommend? Yes.
Would I say Iss best Bioshock GG"? No.
Would I try out the rotating Fist position? Possibly.

8/10 would drillfist again

reviewText: I hate to be the bearer of bad news, but I have to say that Bioshock 2 is a very lackluster sequel to the marvelous, original Bioshock. It's not that Bioshock 2 sucks. Don't get me wrong, it's a great game. What it lacks most though, are improvements. Much of the game felt like an addon to the first Bioshock. There are new areas to explore and new weapons, but that's all that's new. You do get to dual wield plasmids and weapons, but as exciting as that sounds, it's not much of a departure from the first game. Fortunately, the strength of the original's story still resonates in its sequel. The plot is still captivating and there are still the twist and turns we've come to love as a fan of Bioshock. As for the multiplayer, all I have to say is that it sucks.\n\nGrade: B

les than you can create bumdrilling splicers in the entire game) and continues the atmosphere of the first game in most aspects. reviewText:
So after a five day binge play of the BioShock franchise, here are my thoughts about the second installment. And though I'm going to recommend this title, I want to caveat the fact that it is by far, the worst in the franchise. It's well worth picking up on sale due to the fact that its story line reflects on the other two titles, but not worth it's asking price. Lets get into why....

I was warned by a friend that this game was sub par to the original BioShock, but at first blush I was confused as to why. It looked like a vast improvement, with brushed up graphics, new weapons, new enemies, and the ability to play as a Big Daddy. All things that should have made this a block buster game, but are handled so poorly that in the end it actually leaves you very disappointed.

Where to start..... The brushed up graphics at first seem to be a big improvement over the original. They fix one of my gripes about the first game with plenty of new Splicers, each with different voices and outfits, they even added new types of Big Daddy. The problem with this is that you eventually notice that what they've done is remove the glassy, 40s stylized look from the first game, and made everyone look more realistic". reviewText:
Having just completed it, this is probably one of my most favourite games ever. I played the first Bioshock game years ago on the Xbox 360 and so had explored Rapture before; but I didn't really know what to expect upon coming back to the franchise. The storyline is very compelleing, though finding most of the audio recorders is crucial to understanding all of the plot and setting, in my opinion. The combat feels much more involved and chaotic than Bioshock, with so many different weapons and abilities to choose from; you really would need a few playthroughs to be able to use them and/or upgrade them all. The plasmids (abilities) of this game are by far the gem of the game and much fun can be had from using different combinations.

However, there are some bad points to this PC port of the game regarding the technical aspect of it; the most frustrating being 'failed to load save game file' and random crashes to desktop. I have left solutions for these at the bottom of the review. It's a shame the game has not patched and had this game not been gifted to me and I instead purchased it; I would be feeling quite annoyed.

Still, it wasn't enough to ruin this masterpiece of a game. Everything in this game is so refined, the combat, the highly detailed and dynamic world which always keeps you on your toes, the element of reward for compulsive loot checkers like myself and the dialogue and ambience of the dystopican Rapture is brilliantly crafted. There are multiple endings to the game depending on your actions within the storyline. In some games this feels like a useless feature but in Bioshock 2 your actions have real tangile results so think your choices through carefully. Even with the problems of this game, I would thoroughly recommend it.

TECHNICAL FIXES:[/b]
The save issue can be rectified by entering the ini file and rewriting the save file location to your current drive.
Crash to desktop I believe this is unfixable. All I did was quicksave often and I never really lost any progress in the game when it did crash.
Incorrect mouse sensitivity The game does not seem to save the correct mouse sensitivty setting. Upon resuming the game, go into the control menu and click 'apply' again before unpausing the game; this should resume the correct mouse settings.

reviewText:
Bioshock 2 is a sequel to the original game and was developed by 2K Marin. The game, taking place roughly seven years after Bioshock, follows the story of Subject Delta, an early prototype Big Daddy, as he tries to reunites himself with his original Little Sister while trying to survive the danger of a derelict Rapture, now under the command of a psychiatrist, Sophia Lamb, with total opposite philosophical views from Andrew Ryan.
As far as gameplay goes, Bioshock 2 doesn't introduce anything exactly breathtaking over the first game's formula, only tweaking some elements and adding some novelities along the line. The biggest difference between the first and the second game is that now you can fire plasmids and weapons at the same time, hack security machines and other mechanism remotely thanks to a dedicated tool, several enemies from the original game are now more dangerous one way or the other and you'll have to face far more kinds of elite enemies (and not all of them are Big Daddies). As far as general difficulty goes Bioshock 2 manages to be a mixed bag: while the opposition you will encounter is far more deadly than the one in the first game, you are given plenty of new plasmids, tonics and weapons to compensate, and, much like the other games in the series, Bioshock 2 actually becomes easier as you progress into it.
The story of Bioshock 2 was recived in a variety of ways. The main plot is, at its core, a self-insert fic which tries to expand the characters and the story of the first game while introducing some new elements that however do tend to make little sense at times (the biggest problem here being that we are introduced to new characters and events that were supposedly of major importance in Rapture's history, and therefore should had been mentioned in the original Bioshock too). There is also some consent that the plot of the original game didn't need an expansion whatsoever. Still, Bioshock 2 manages to tell a fairly good story on its own thanks to a cast of (mostly) interesting and emotional characters. The game also features a rudimentary moral system: depending of few decisions you are called to make regarding the Little Sisters and some major NPCs, you can get a different ending.
Bioshock 2 also features a multiplayer mode, dubbed The Fall of Rapture". However

Absolutely fabulous game, just like bioshock originall.
If you want more of the same, just a little bit updated and such, then buy it!

1. Looks better then the original, and looks good even when playing in 2015.
2. Gameplay is nothing special, but it is good, plus fun ways to kill with weird weapons and plasmids (just like in the original).

5. multiplayer I think? I have no idea I haven't touched it, and honestly forgot to look at it. Still better then not having one at all though! right guys?

Cons:
1. While better looking then the original, it still doesn't look like infinite. (captain obvious).
2. Ragdoll animations still look like they are running on a lower framerate then the rest of the game just like in the original.
3. story not as gripping as the original.
4. The game copied many plasmids (for example) from bioshock 1.
5. The game froze 2 times for me during my playthrough, I had to edit some launch thing into -dx9 or something like that (it's on all forums) and then I never had a problem again.

If you played bioshock 1 and loved it like me, then buy this and play some more!

reviewText:
Bioshock 2 is an older game now (nearly 4 years!) and has been reviewed many times; I'll repeat one thing that was common to a lot of those: If you liked Bioshock, you'll like Bioshock 2.  It doesn't have _quite_ as much impact as the former, largely due to the change of protagonist.

As Jack, even spliced up, you felt small.  Human.  Vulnerable.  There was a mile of freezing seawater between you and escape, and the lunatics had free run of the asylum... and drowning was something you would have no problem doing.  As Subject Delta (or, in Minerva's Den, Subject Sigma), you feel like a Big Daddy.  A little ponderous, but armoured, tough, and more than capable of beating a few splicers to death.

The story isn't quite as brilliant either - in the first game, Rapture was new (to you), and everything was exploration of Andrew Ryan's ruined dream.  Well, in 2, Rapture is just as pretty, just as fascinating... but not quite as new.  There's a certain sense of familiarity for those who've played through the first game and spent quite a few hours in the slowly decaying city.  It's worth noting that as with the first game, the art assets for Bioshock 2 are stunning.  Post-apocalyptic art deco and water effects make for a feast for the eyes.

Some of the new Plasmids (plus the ability to use guns and plasmids at the same time) make for some real fun, mechanically, and even if you're feeling like a nice, tough Big Daddy, the Splicers haven't been sitting still either.  There are some real challenges at the higher difficulty levels.

Overall, if you don't have it, but have played Bioshock, get this game, and play it.  If you don't have it, and _haven't_ played Bioshock, get Bioshock.  Then get this game and play it. :)

reviewText:
Originally posted on March 16, 2010

Bioshock 2 is the full fledged sequel to Bioshock, although at times it feels more like an expansion pack to the original...

Gameplay-
The gameplay of Bioshock 2 is largely an improvement over the original, with the player taking on the role of a Big Daddy prototype instead of Jack. Prototype is the operative word here, however, as with the exception of having a drill and clunky sound effects when moving or jumping, you never really feel like a big daddy. Splicers can often cause you large amounts of damage with small arms or melee weapons in only a few hits, which is very similar to the first game. I understand why this choice was made, for balance purposes, and I actually largely agree with it, but the feeling of being a clunking metal behemoth is never really there.

However, on an overall level, the sequel makes several key improvements. simultaneous usage of plasmids and weapons make combat much more fluid and satisfying, and the introduction of new enemies (alphas, brutes, big sisters) and the revamping of old ones (spider splicers, rumbler daddies) really contribute to this. Also, the game feels a good deal harder than the original without sacrificing the ability to make gameplay choices, and this is partially accomplished by upping the ante of combat. Where before you would only see 2-3 splicers an engagement, in Bioshock 2 it is not uncommon to engage a brute or two and 3-4 leadhead splicers in the same area.

The adopt/save/harvest mechanic with the little sisters works very well, allowing you to kill big daddies as before, and choose whether to a) harvest them right away b) have them gather ADAM for you and then harvest them c) save them right away d) have them gather and then save them. Obviously the best choice either way is to have them harvest ADAM from special corpses in the level first to get more ADAM, but this adds a great deal of moral and gameplay depth to the little sister dynamic. Plus, having the little sister ride on your shoulders and comment on combat as you go along is at times hilarious, or just cute, and a little sad. A very nice touch. Messing with the little sisters angers the big sisters, who often come for you after you've dealt with most of the little sisters in the level. They serve as improvised and random boss-fights, and are most definitely a challenge. They add a new source of tension (and ADAM) to the Bioshock formula.

Another gameplay change is the revamped Plasmid and Gene Tonic system. Plasmids at higher levels (2,3) have differentiated visual and gameplay effects, such as being able to charge up for more powerful attacks and shoot streams of elemental damage. They add a great deal of gameplay variety and re-playability. In addition, gene tonics are now all organized into one large slot, a welcome change, and some new ones have appeared that cover multiple effects, such as the elemental gene tonics. Finally, research remains useful but has been streamlined with a few minor tweaks.

Finally, the much touted ocean underwater sequences remain a pretty but relatively gimmicky and useless area of gameplay, where you are basically placed in a tunnel from one airlock to another. They are incredibly atmospheric, but they serve very little gameplay purpose other than scrounging.

Visuals-
Bioshock 2 is the full fledged sequel to Bioshock, although visually speaking it feels more like an expansion pack to the original. The game runs on the same engine as the original from 2007, and while innovations have been made in art design and level design, the same graphics remain largely untouched. The same low-res textures and effects are intact, and with the exception of new plasmid effects and a few minor tweaks, the technical graphics remain the same as they were in 2007. This is very upsetting, but it is an industry wide trend, and consoles are almost entirely responsible. Therefore, Bioshock 2 will not be penalized too harshly.

Artistically, the game does not disappoint, and the sound effects that accompany these new designs create a great atmosphere for the city of Rapture that feels fresh the second time around. New posters, new music, new character models, new weapons, and new effects.

Story-
In addition, the story, which has received some flak from Gamespot and other websites, is surprisingly good, and the audio diaries continue a wonderful trend from the first game that add a great deal of back story to Rapture and the tale of Andrew Ryan that newcomers and especially fans of the first game will love. Phoebe Lamb is the near antithesis of Andrew Ryan, and just as villainous for it, which is a refreshing change of pace. The ability to kill or spare certain key characters and the fact that such choices actually do have an impact on the story really adds to the replay value here. While the plot lacks the holy s**t" factor of the original
date: it is quite well written and acted

The gameplay is arguably improved a bit from the first game, with a broader weapon set and extra polish, as well as some tweaked plasmids (Security Command is a fun one- lets you summon flying security bots wherever you are). However, the storyline feels a bit grindy and aimless, with the main character's goals feeling relatively unmotivated compared to those in the first game Yeah, he's dying, but for some reason it just doesn't feel compelling. You never actually meet two of the big characters in the game- Sinclair and Sofia Lamb- in any major role physically, so they just feel like voices in your head for most of the game. Also, this game is as glitchy as the first, if not more, and will probably crash you out to the desktop more than a couple times. Quicksave will be your best friend.\n\nReservations aside, I highly recommend this game, because the slight complaints I have are well worth sticking through for the experience of the game as a whole.

reviewText:
While I do recommend this game, do not think that there are not some things that are less than acceptable =

Story- The story is a bit more dumbed down then the first one. The gist of it is you’re a prototype Big Daddy who got resurrected and you need to find your little sister (now grown up). On your journey, you go through misadventure to misadventure. Overall, not the strongest out of the Bioshock series

Gameplay- Gameplay is more polished and improved from the first game. While there are very few new plasmids, the old ones are improved and have more development than the first game (For example, Electro Bolt at Level 3 can shoot a stream of electricity and chain lightning) Gunplay is also very fun, but some weapons are better left untouched at a Power to the People station than others. Overall, solid and entertaining

Graphics- The models are a step up from the first game, now more polished and scary looking. Environments are similar to the first game, but with improved textures and a more abandoned feel. In sum, an upgrade from the first game.

Control- The controls were fine. You can now duel wield a plasmid and a weapon. Switching weapons and plasmids in a fight could become tricky, but isn't a major fault that affects the game.

Difficulty- Identical to the first game, with the added challenge of being limited to 5 medkits and 5 EVE hypos. Most of the time it’s a fair incline, but be prepared to gluttonously consume medkit after medkit during some fights.

Polishes- Hacking is improved (Replacing long boring tube puzzles with quick button pressing) Plasmids are fun to use and they defiantly spice up the gameplay. Research is also more innovative, making the player contribute.

Low Points- Games for Windows Live (GFWL) sucks. There, I said it. I recommend finding a way to disable it and adding -dx9 to launch options (Oh and stay away from multiplayer if you don't want a sour taste to be left in your mouth). Also, you can't go back to previous areas, so better scavenge the area well.

Final Verdict: 7.5/10

Bioshock 2 improves upon the first game (gameplay wise), making it more enjoyable to play. However, the games basic plot and lack of social/political commentary may leave some fans disappointed. If you want a game that improves upon the first gameplay wise, but lacks any real voice, I recommend this. Otherwise, it's best to save up $10.00 more to buy Infinite

reviewText:
Having just completed it, this is probably one of my most favourite games ever. I played the first Bioshock game years ago on the Xbox 360 and so had explored Rapture before; but I didn't really know what to expect upon coming back to the franchise. The storyline is very compelleing, though finding most of the audio recorders is crucial to understanding all of the plot and setting, in my opinion. The combat feels much more involved and chaotic than Bioshock, with so many different weapons and abilities to choose from; you really would need a few playthroughs to be able to use them and/or upgrade them all. The plasmids (abilities) of this game are by far the gem of the game and much fun can be had from using different combinations.

However, there are some bad points to this PC port of the game regarding the technical aspect of it; the most frustrating being 'failed to load save game file' and random crashes to desktop. I have left solutions for these at the bottom of the review. It's a shame the game has not patched and had this game not been gifted to me and I instead purchased it; I would be feeling quite annoyed.

Still, it wasn't enough to ruin this masterpiece of a game. Everything in this game is so refined, the combat, the highly detailed and dynamic world which always keeps you on your toes, the element of reward for compulsive loot checkers like myself and the dialogue and ambience of the dystopican Rapture is brilliantly crafted. There are multiple endings to the game depending on your actions within the storyline. In some games this feels like a useless feature but in Bioshock 2 your actions have real tangile results so think your choices through carefully. Even with the problems of this game, I would thoroughly recommend it.

TECHNICAL FIXES:[/b]
The save issue can be rectified by entering the ini file and rewriting the save file location to your current drive.
Crash to desktop I believe this is unfixable. All I did was quicksave often and I never really lost any progress in the game when it did crash.
Incorrect mouse sensitivity The game does not seem to save the correct mouse sensitivty setting. Upon resuming the game, go into the control menu and click 'apply' again before unpausing the game; this should resume the correct mouse settings.

reviewText:
This entry in the BioShock series is, to me, a polarizing experience.

Standing on its own, this game is incredible. The art design is absolutely mesmerizing, complemented with a sensual soundtrack and astounding voice work. The gameplay is quite intuitive as well; guns feel distinct and your entire arsenal is an equillibrium of diverse offense. Plasmids feel unique and the inclusion of traps allows for a meticulous, strategic approach when protecting Little Sisters' and their harvesting. BioShock 2 succeeds in these aspects, though it falters in others.

Comparing this game with BioShock 1, however, proves much dissonance. While BioShock 1 provided enough backstory to support necessary explanation for things in the universe, BioShock 2 unloaded an excess- it feels forced, uninspired, and ultimately like fan fiction. The new information given in BioShock 2 doesn't mesh very well with what BioShock 1 established- the tone of the subject matter feels radically different between the two. The story of this game feels as though it lacks true progression of any sort, and ultimately hinders in pacing and character development. To make this game feel more as if it didn't belong in the main canon, it was entirely neglected in both episodes of Burial at Sea for BioShock Infinite- no mention of any characters, foreshadowing of any sort, and even entirely negates some of things established in BioShock 2.

BioShock 2 is a love/hate game- on its own, it stands quite fine. When compared to BioShock 1, it feels entirely unnecesary and unfitting.

reviewText:
Bioshock 2 is a direct sequel to Bioshock, and as such can be directly measured up to it's predecessor. How well does it compare to the original?
Well, both games have their own experience to give; both games have their own stories, characters and themes to follow, both games I feel have individual strengths over the other which makes both of them stand out. Bioshock 2 is a different journey through the dilapidated streets of Rapture, there are new locations to explore, new secrets to uncover, new weapons to use and new enemies to use them on...
To start out on what I feel are direct improvements over the previous game: The process of hacking machines has been improved tenfold, it's no longer a distracting element that takes the player out of the environment temporarily so they can solve a puzzle, it's a sequence of actions and reactions that tests the players reflexes and rewards them for success. Instead of a frustrating puzzle it's a needle simply moving back and forth waiting for the player to activate it while it's over a green area of the meter, this is a vast improvement over Bioshock 1 in my opinion because it's not distracting in the slightest, and instead of giving the player a massive mess to sort out its a simple imput system thats easy to use and understand.
The options on how to manage Little Sisters is a much more engaging experience, you can choose to harvest or adopt them temporarily. Adopting them gives you the option to use them to harvest Adam from corpses, which can increase your Adam intake by a large sum while still keeping your conscience clean, afterwards you can take them to a vent and again you are given the option to rescue or harvest them, what you do is your choice.

Now to summarize the rest of the game: The story places you in the role of Subject Delta, an early prototype of the infamous Big Daddies: Your Little Sister has been taken from you and you have been killed in the process only to be revived by a Vita-Chamber, with no recollection of how you ended up there your only goal is to reuinite with your Little Sister, Elanor Lamb. To do this you must brave the run-down streets of Rapture which have seen eight years of neglect since the events of the first game. All the while the story reacts to your choices on how to deal with Little Sisters and other NPCs, giving the player one of (from what I understand) several different endings.
Throughout Rapture you will come across some familiar enemies, Splicers, and some new blood-thirsy additions to the stock. Notably the Big Sisters, the Brute Splicers, the Rumbler Big Daddies and the Alpha Series. Each of the new enemies gives a lot more to the experience and are spread out, keeping the game from being unjustly overwhelming. The new weapons are a lot of fun to use and are adaptive to your respective playstyle thanks to the alternative ammunitions available to each one, allowing the player to be either extremely aggressive, you can be exploitive of your enemies weaknesses or being defensive setting up clever traps. The weapons and Plasmids, like Bioshock 1, are all reactive, fun to use and have a good powerful feeling to them. I'm especially fond of the spear gun, that little gem will forever hold a special place in my heart.
Levels are again fun, flawless and well paced, with plenty of opportunity to explore and discover, and in doing so the player is rewarded with extra ammo and health as well as audio diaries delivering exposition to Rapture's recent years or not-so-ancient past. Not to mention the jaw-dropping visuals, haunting soundtrack and out-of-this-world graphics.

Now the question that will always nag at me: Do I like this game or the original Bioshock more? All points and aspects considered I will have to go with the original. I like the story and characters so much more, it delivered a larger impact to me about a man struggling to break free of the chains keeping him enslaved without him even knowing it. Where Bioshock 2 takes on a sort of rescue story, which doesn't lend itself to the kind of tale that can justify the sheer amount of discovery that Rapture offers.

Ultimately Bioshock 2 cannot compete with its predecessor (but what can? That game was almost perfect in every regard), but still its a great game thats well thought-out and is a lot of fun to play through, keeping the elements of the original in place while giving the player some new toys to use.

And before I forget: Users of DirectX 10 like myself will encounter crashing problems as they try to play, please refer to this guide for a long list of possible solutions:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=210917941
Thanks to the writer of this guide for letting me enjoy this game to it's fullest potential without interruption.

Purchased at $5

reviewText: Bioshock 2 provides an interesting second look at the world of Rapture, expanding on the story set by the first game. The gameplay is arguably improved a bit from the first game, with a broader weapon set and extra polish, as well as some tweaked plasmids (Security Command is a fun one- lets you summon flying security bots wherever you are). However, the storyline feels a bit grindy and aimless, with the main character's goals feeling relatively unmotivated compared to those in the first game Yeah, he's dying, but for some reason it just doesn't feel compelling. You never actually meet two of the big characters in the game- Sinclair and Sofia Lamb- in any major role physically, so they just feel like voices in your head for most of the game. Also, this game is as glitchy as the first, if not more, and will probably crash you out to the desktop more than a couple times. Quicksave will be your best friend.\n\nReservations aside, I highly recommend this game, because the slight complaints I have are well worth sticking through for the experience of the game as a whole.

reviewText:
Ah, Bioshock 2. The scrawny, overlooked middle child of the Bioshock franchise. Neither the adrenaline-soaked action of Infinite, nor the dark, atmospheric journey of discovery of the original. Now that I've played it I can see why it was a let down for many.

Here is an example of when worlds collide for the worst. The ability to wield the power of the Sith in one hand and the power of the Terminator in the other does not suit the dreary tromp through Rapture's half flooded tunnels. It's an action game in a horror setting, where the action overwhelms any sense of dread, knowing that whatever pops around the corner will find themselves just another red smear on the soggy carpet in the blink of an eye.

Writing is far weaker than the original. Sofia Lamb is a little more than Andrew Ryan, except she was found in the clearance aisle of Villains R Us. Like Ryan, she calls out your actions throughout the game, but never succeeds in getting under your skin. Minor villains come and go with no significant buildup nor payoff. The moral choice system is back, too. Just as useless as it was in the first game.

Speaking of mechanics, playing as a Big Daddy turns the 'Little Sister Escort' level from the original game into a game mechanic, again with the ability to save or harvest them once their Adam collecting is done. The 'save or harvest' aka 'good or evil' mechanic was already pretty gimmiky in the original game and even more so now. Any player who pays any amount of attention to escorting Little Sisters will be positively swimming in Adam, without a single harvest.

All in all, though, Bioshock 2 is still a worthy game, despite feeling more 'DLC' than 'sequel'. It does an admirable job of expanding upon the lore of the original game and fielded some new mechanics that would be refined and put to greater use in Infinite. Had it not need to follow in the footsteps of the original Bioshock it likely would have fared far better than it did.

On the note of Bioshock Infinite, the similarities between Bioschocks 2 and Infinite are quite noticeable. Beyond the mechanics there's the father-daughter team, with the daughter as a support character, going up against a deluded tyrant insane with the goal of utopia. There's the insane religious dudes, the frustrated minority, sick of discrimination, and the painting of the protagonist as the harbinger of doom to a close-knit society. Get the feeling that, like Subject Delta, this game is a prototype. At least it's a fun one.

reviewText:
A sequel worthy of its precedessor.
Bioshock 2 makes you jump right into the known an deep setting with familiar set of mechanics that went through slight alterations and refreshement; most noticeable with plasmids that suddenly became a much more interesting and versatile tool that doesn't force you to stop gunning. A change needed for the more action-y nature of the game when compared to the original Bioshock.

While the gameplay feels very familiar, the storytelling isn't. The difference comes from the fact that the first game was all about introducing the player to Rapture and telling him the story of it. What was driving us all was the discovery, walking through the city that fell from its glory and plunged into darkness. That, and a very well constructed plot with just the right amount of surprises.
You won't find that in the sequel - we know the place, we know the story. The plot got much simpler. What is it about, then? Feelings. Bioshock made you listen to the tale, yet stay a bit to the side. Bioshock 2, on the other hand, sacrifices some of it to make you feel and experience the Rapture as  Big Daddy. It's pulled off very well, and keeps the game on high level even if it is nto married to the same idea as the original. Gathering, protecting, curing, harvesting - it all feels more personal now. Same how it is for all the encounters with the 'main NPCs', which you can kill or spare. They all are relevant to who you play. You are not a 'stranger', but a part of the city. This aspect, and the general attitude of resorting to showing instead of telling gives this one a unique charm.

reviewText:
I can't actually recommend Bioshock 2 by itself. It's a superb Unreal shooter wrapped in mediocre level design and story. The gunplay is worthy of a sequel to Bioshock, but the story itself fails in one key point: making you care about the characters that occupy the world. Bioshock 1 had great pacing for introducing characters that seemed reasonable and slowly descended into the realm of madness as the game progressed - 2 just throws you into the madhouse and asks that you kindly shoot it up.

There are tons of brilliant and unique ideas in Bioshock 2, but they're missing that master touch - it's like a poor imitiation without really understanding the reasoning behind the design decisions of the first game. I have no doubt that with another 8 months and a rewrite the game could've been stellar. If you really like the shooting, then by all means play the main campaign, but that's about all you're going to get from it.

The multiplayer is dead nowadays, but it was one of the better Unreal experiences online when it launched since it relied on the excellent gunplay and plasmid mechanics of the campaign.

The reason I am recommending this game (on sale) is because of the DLC. Minerva's Den is an excellent piece of design, in both level and story. It's a phenomenal experience and is convincingly alive in the world of Bioshock. Buy the game and DLC (again on sale) and play Minerva's Den. The pacing, writing, dialogue, and thought that went into it is worth of some real Bioshock material. Game: 5/10, DLC: 10/10

reviewText:
Purchased at $5

There's no denying that its a stunning game, visually. In fact its probably the most colorful FPS in recent years. Dont sit too close though, or all that saturation will hurt your eyes.

The gameplay has definitely been improved. Dual wielding is very nice, the weapon selection is much more pleasing, and your Big Daddy character has some new moves and better melee.

Beyond that....everything else falls short. Audio is bugged I think. I know its supposed to sound like you're in a fishbowl helmet, but that doesn't mean that weapon fire and explosions should randomly go completely MUTE. I spent 2 hours searching for a solution and....nothing.

The story completely lost me after just 30 minutes. I couldn't bring myself to care at all. You will have a neat ally at the end of the game, however...

*Edit*

GFWL was removed and this game was reborn on steam with free DLC for all existing owners. I heard Minerva's Den was good but I'm getting a lot of annoying crashes these days, and I don't care to try and diagnose the issue.

reviewText:
Bioshock 2 is a sequel to the original game and was developed by 2K Marin. The game, taking place roughly seven years after Bioshock, follows the story of Subject Delta, an early prototype Big Daddy, as he tries to reunites himself with his original Little Sister while trying to survive the danger of a derelict Rapture, now under the command of a psychiatrist, Sophia Lamb, with total opposite philosophical views from Andrew Ryan.
As far as gameplay goes, Bioshock 2 doesn't introduce anything exactly breathtaking over the first game's formula, only tweaking some elements and adding some novelities along the line. The biggest difference between the first and the second game is that now you can fire plasmids and weapons at the same time, hack security machines and other mechanism remotely thanks to a dedicated tool, several enemies from the original game are now more dangerous one way or the other and you'll have to face far more kinds of elite enemies (and not all of them are Big Daddies). As far as general difficulty goes Bioshock 2 manages to be a mixed bag: while the opposition you will encounter is far more deadly than the one in the first game, you are given plenty of new plasmids, tonics and weapons to compensate, and, much like the other games in the series, Bioshock 2 actually becomes easier as you progress into it.
The story of Bioshock 2 was recived in a variety of ways. The main plot is, at its core, a self-insert fic which tries to expand the characters and the story of the first game while introducing some new elements that however do tend to make little sense at times (the biggest problem here being that we are introduced to new characters and events that were supposedly of major importance in Rapture's history, and therefore should had been mentioned in the original Bioshock too). There is also some consent that the plot of the original game didn't need an expansion whatsoever. Still, Bioshock 2 manages to tell a fairly good story on its own thanks to a cast of (mostly) interesting and emotional characters. The game also features a rudimentary moral system: depending of few decisions you are called to make regarding the Little Sisters and some major NPCs, you can get a different ending.
Bioshock 2 also features a multiplayer mode, dubbed The Fall of Rapture". However
recommended: this mode has been pretty much abbandoned and it's downright impossible to meet other players
hoursPlayed: let alone start any match. It's worth mentioning that Bioshock 2 multiplayer wasn't exactly that well recived though.\nAs it stands

reviewText:
In Bioshock 2 you revisit rapture 10 years after the events of Bioshock 1, you start off as a ''Prototype'' Big Daddy on a quest to save your little sister.

Bioshock 2's gameplay is a huge improvement from its predecessor giving you the ability to use your weapon and plasmids at the same time and a completely new hacking system, Bioshock 2 also gives you the old feel of constantly being prepared for anything and long winded fights with Big Daddies and Big Sisters leaves you at the end of your seat 90% of the time.

Bioshock 2's plot line is very straight forward with a lot fewer plot-twists and creativeness to the characters as Bioshock 1, yet it is unique in its own way. When I played the campaign I felt totally immersed into the plot making relate to the main characters and feel his emotions, pains and troubles. I felt like the story had meaning to the game and what I would do would affect the outcome of the game's ending (which it did).

The only gripe I had with the game was the Splicers, the lower-tier Splicers were complete Bullet Sponges at times and could deal TONNES of damage if you weren't careful.


Expect some tears, laughing, suspense and the sheer craziness of what Bioshock is praised for!

9/10 - Would you kindly play again...

reviewText:
I had plenty of time to enjoy the Bioshock and Bioshock 2 series in the past week.

I did not skip through the content like it was there for no reason, I've listened to audio logs, opened every chest in game and tried to kill everything that needed killing. I had a blast with Bioshock 1. Smooth experience, no crashes and an overall satisfaction. The end of Bioshock was kinda if-y but hey it was a really good game.

Now what can I say about Bioshock 2? Well it was a great game, to be honest I liked the mechanics more than the first part and the story was so intense and beautiful that I got sucked into it and finished the game in 2 days. I will strongly suggest if you haven't played bioshock series to play do so.

Now the problems with Bioshock 2.... O My F%#@*! GOD ! ! !
First of all I had to spend quite some time figuring out a way to start the game since it was not loading at all and after a two days of brainstorming and forums-searching I found nothing. Then I've decided to delete it and re-install + the already unavailable Games for Windows Live and somehow, somewhat it started.

The first 15 minutes of the game were awesome and suddenly CRASH ... like what ?!?
Ok no problem I re-started the game and ... nope you've guessed it no auto save every 5 minutes or so, had to start from the beggining. This kept happening until I finished the game, every other hour or so I was getting a crash with no error message, no NOTHING. I did read some forums and tried all the turn off DX10 thing and resolution change and logs and well nothing helped.

What I'd strongly reccomend is make QUICK SAVE on a keybind that you will be using atleast every 5-10 minutes, otherwise if you get sucked into the game and forget to save it it will return you back at your last auto save (which is either the beggining of the mission or a very important transition) and believe me after a while it gets frustrating (A LOT!!!).

The game is intense if played on the right difficulty, the story is incredible and a good ending to the Bioshock series but the CRASHES are terrible and made me thing of leaving this game. Just finish it and I hope you don't have the same issues as I did but hey its the same thing, different pc :) (Windows 8.1 btw and my machine is really strong)

Hope you enjoy the game and I wish it is a crash free experience for you :)

reviewText:
A much better game than the first one, despite being less exploration-based.  Also has many fewer issues with WIndows 7.

+ Graphics look pretty much the same as the original.  The humans look a lot better, though.
+ Much better gunplay.  Same amount of weapons, but this time, you can dual-wield them with plasmids.  The melee weapon is a drill, and it's actually useful to the point where you could play the entire game dashing and smashing ♥♥♥♥ing everything.  The pistol is now a more powerful rivet gun, the tommygun is now a gatling gun, the single-barrel shotgun is now a supershotgun, etc. Switching between plasmids is a bit of a chore.
+ Better, faster hacking mechanics that didn't feel like ♥♥♥♥.

- Levels aren't as expansive as the original.  They're more linear, which I didn't mind, but it might be a deal-breaker for some.
- There are still a few issues with the port, especially in Fontaine Futuristics where I had the game crash many times.  This time, thankfully, your keybinds don't get wiped.
- The FOV thing still happens.  Not that terrible since you can use a keybind to set your FOV, but it still happens when you zoom in with the speargun.
- Game's easier than the original, partly due to the better guns. Again, it's a console shooter.
- No final boss this time, just a final wave of enemies.  I wouldn't mind having Big Daddy Sinclair be the final boss, with more attacks and more health.

If you liked the first Bioshock, get this one too.

reviewText:
Most things from BioShock apply to BioShock 2, so I'll do the rundown on changes.

2 Quick discalimers:
1-It crashes, a lot, and seemingly for no reason. It doesn't autosave as much as I wanted it to, so save often!
2-The scarier moments from BioShock are pretty much gone (make of that what you will), so if you're not a horror fan, you'll probably enjoy this a bit more than BioShock, but it's still pretty bloody.

So you're a Big Daddy by the name of 'Subject Delta', but you can still use Plasmids and such, because your a prototype. Your little sister, now a grown-up sister, needs your help after you get ressurected. The story is above average, but overall weaker than BioShock. Similar progression to BioShock as well, semi-linear missions but plenty of exploring for cakes and ammo. We've also got some new characters to go with our new areas too. Another change I like is the visual style. Set 8 years after BioShock, Rapture's leak problem has got a little...bigger...to say the least. The art deco style has been preserved, but there's odd glowing underwater plants and stuff, and the sequences where you get to wander around on the ocean floor are really beautiful. I spent the first 10-ish minutes going 'Whoa, everything's so pretty!'.
Gameplay is largely the same, except now we can dual wield Plasmids and Weapons, a much needed improvement, and a full new host of weapons as well. Plasmids are largely the same, but some changes and additions, usual sequel things. I also found I was using a greater variety of weapons and Plasmids than BioShock, where I was often just using Electro-Bolt and the Machine Gun, Gene tonics are more streamlined, so you only have 1 HUGE set of Gene Tonics, which is rather nice as in BioShock, I was often thinking 'gawd, I need more combat tonic slots!'. Hacking isn't total ♥♥♥♥ anymore, just a kinda Quicktime event, but you can still screw up, and you can also hack from a distance, hooray! Enemies are largely the same, two new types of Big Daddy and one new Splicer is all I've seen so far. So pretty solid all round, nothing too different from the original, but some much needed changes.

However, BioShock 2 does have a fair swathe of problems. The story isn't as good as before, which is a real weakness. The main antagonist has the most annoying voice ever, and she's always around, but the other characters are fine. As a Big Daddy, when you get to a Little Sister, you have two options: 1-'Adopt' her, take her to a corpse, gather some ADAM as you munch through half your health and Ammo after fighting a butt-ton of Splicers, then do it again, and finally send her to a vent, and I don't think you even get rewards unlike BioShock. Or, 2-Kill her on the spot, 120 ADAM, bam, no fuss, lots of mess, but no uneccesary usage of Health kits.
On the note of Health and EVE Hypos: You can only carry 5 of each, but First Aid Kits fully heal you. I found I was often low of health. And it annoys me how you can eat, drink and smoke through your steel diving helmet, unless Subject Delta can absorb nutrients through Osmosis or something.
When you are dealing with Little Sisters, there's a chance it can summon a Big Sister, a kind of Mini-Boss. They're kind of annoying, but not a huge ♥♥♥♥ to deal, and you are given proper warning. But please, ONLY spawn one if we're being evil and harvesting them, NOT protecting them with our lives and finally freeing them from their torment.
The other two problems are more technical. I found the Audio was very quiet, everything was quite distant most of the time, which is really annoying, especially when sound is so important. The other problem is buttons. Although being able to dual wield is nice, there's a lot of extra keys, and it can get a bit cluttered. Due to too many keys, there's no manual way to reload EVE, which is a real pain in the middle of a fight, so you have to zap yourself to 0, then reload, which is about as fast as the original.

But overall, BioShock 2 is still solid. It's kind of like Portal and Portal 2. They're both good games, but BioShock is superior to BioShock 2. The story is less tight than before, and there's some dangling threads here and there. BioShock 2 also has the morality element present, but it's handled a lot better, a bit more grey. And I genuinelly felt sad with the ending I got.

reviewText:
While I feel that this game has the weakest story out of all the games in the Bioshock trilogy, I definitely believe Bioshock 2 has the best gameplay. For one, dual wielding has been added, meaning you don't need to wait for your character to switch between having a weapon and plasmid out in the heat of battle. Because you play as a Big Daddy, the game has expanded upon the ways you can collect Adam to upgrade your plasmids. Like before, you can choose to harvest or rescue Little Sisters, but now you can also escort Little Sisters around so they can harvest Adam off of corpses for you. Also, hacking has been drastically improved. Not only can you now hack machines from a distance, but also the pipe minigame has been removed, being replaced with an extremely brief timing-based minigame that will make you want to hack things much more frequently than you did in the original.

This is also the only Bioshock game to have a Multiplayer mode. It's a fun distraction, but it didn't really appeal to me as something I'd wanna dedicate my time towards, especially considering how small the multiplayer community is now. I never was unable to find a server to play on, but that's only because there's often only 1 or 2 servers available. That being said, the achievements in the Multiplayer are not only rare, but easy to obtain, so it might be worth checking out if you're into that.

One final thing I want to point out is the Minerva's Den DLC. This extra campaign is definitely worth picking up, as it's extremely well written and designed. It's definitely better than the main storyline.

All in all, Bioshock 2 is a fun Bioshock experience. That being said, I'd mainly recommend it to people who are already fans of the Bioshock series, as the changes that have been added to the gameplay aren't really enough to satisfy considering the underwhelming storyline. Basically, if you've played Bioshock and want more of the gameplay, play this. If on the other hand you've played the original and want more of the storyline, play Infinite and it's Burial at Sea DLC.

reviewText:
Outstanding game and sequel, I actually enjoyed Bioshock 2 more than the original due to the new weapons like auto turrets, rivet gun & the drill. I liked the fact that the game emphasised using strategy and teamwork at times in contrast to just mowing down all the enemies by yourself and the auto turrets were especially a nice addition which complimented this.

In terms of the story, Bioshock 2 had a few twists but I felt the story wasn't as fleshed out this time around, however don't be mistaken, as the story is still very powerful in Bioshock 2 and is by no means a slouch. There was plenty of new characters who had convincing back stories and the game also alluded to some of the characters from the previous game which was a nice touch.

On the contrary though, the plasmids could of been updated a little more as if memory serves they were the same ones from the original so it would of been nice to see new plasmids. Overall though, i'd definitely reccomend Bioshock 2 to fans of not only the series but fans in the fps genre as well & anybody who enjoys a thought provoking story.

reviewText:
I played both Bioshock & Bioshock 2 back-to-back and in my opinion, this game is far superior to the original. Sure, the first one set the standard, introduced the city and setting but it's really this game that presents a strong narrative, polished gameplay and a great pacing.

While I had a really hard time managing weapons & plasmids in the original game, resulting in numerous unnecessary deaths that left me frustrated and blaming the game rather than me, I found Bioshock 2's gameplay system to be much better and user-friendly.

Still had a great time battling Splicers and fending for my life, but only died once from a strategic mistake rather than because I couldn't select a weapon that still had bullets in it or find the right plasmid to deal that last inch of damage to the enemy.

A must play if you love First Person Shooters!
