reviewText:
(Recommended despite 'boss battle' overload and incongruous vulnerability)

Bioshock 2 is not as innovative, cohesive and thematically sophisticated as the original. That being said, it plays just as well, if not better, due to some much needed design modifications. And the game looks markedly better as well. Its problems lie in the storyline and how it progresses. While the communism v.s. objectivism theme sounds fantastic on paper, it is not as convincing as Bioshock's treatment of objectivism and capitalism. Perhaps it reveals that Ken Levine knew what he was writing about, whereas Bioshock 2 better resembles a summary of Wikipedia pages on the subject. But, if you're there for the gameplay and experience itself, you'll be happy. Combat is smoother; the environment is more detailed and traversing it is more challenging. However, the means to obtain Adam soon grows very tedious.

Remember that section in the first game when you protected a little sister against waves of enemies? In the second game, you don't have a little sister until you defeat another big daddy and take his. Naturally, the combat here is very challenging. However, if you harvest the little sister right then and there, you'll get very little return. Instead, you must let her extract Adam from three designated corpses in the area; each time, you are beset at all sides by enemies who only become stronger the further you advance through the game. Of course, after doing this three times, you are met with the same binary choice as in the first game: harvest or set-free. But don't forget, each area has three big daddies and three little sisters. Once all little sisters are harvested or freed in an area, you'll be forced into an immediate fight to the death with a big sister.

This is what I mean by 'boss battle overload', and it's all the more confusing that the character you're playing should, by all means, BE a boss! It certainly doesn't feel so, as you die just as easily as any human. So, unless you LOVE this gameplay mechanic, you might come to hate hearing the words, look daddy
date: it's an angel!" That being said
recommended: certainly persevere with the game. You just might like to save the expansion
hoursPlayed: Minerva's Den for a while later."

reviewText:
I am Andrew Ryan and I’m here to ask you a question:
Я - Эндрю Райан, и я спрашиваю вас:

Is a man not entitled to the sweat of his own brow?
Неужели человек не имеет права на заработанное в поте лица своего?

No, says the man in Washington.It belongs to the poor.
Нет, говорит Вашингтон. Это принадлежит бедным.

No, says the man in the Vatican. It belongs to God.
Нет, говорит Ватикан. Это принадлежит Богу.

No, says the man in Moscow. It belongs to everyone.
Нет, говорит Москва. Это принадлежит всем.

I rejected those answers. Instead, I chose something different.
Я отверг эти ответы. Вместо них я выбрал нечто иное.

I chose the impossible. I chose....Rapture.
Я выбрал невозможное. Я выбрал...Восторг.

A city where the artist would not fear the censor.
Город, в котором художник не боится цензора.

Where the scientist would not be bound by Petty morality.
Город, где ученые не связаны узкими рамками морали.

Where the great would not be constrained by the small.
Город, где великое не ограничивается малым.

And with the sweat of your brow, Rapture can become your city as well.
И работая в поте лица своего

reviewText: Bioshock 2 is a first person shooter and a sequel to the critical acclaim 2007 game bioshock (i played the first game of bioshock on the Xbox 360), and like the first game you explore Rapture and fight off enemies using a combination of the environment, weapons, plasmids, and tonics. Plasmids and tonics are special genetic-reencoding liquids that grant the user active or passive abilities, respectively, and include many of those introduced in BioShock as well as new ones. plasmids can give the player the ability to use telekinesis or to invoke fire, while tonics can improve the player's movement speed, attack damage, or damage resistance. Several of the weapons in BioShock 2 were previously seen carried by Big Daddies in the first game, including a powerful drill and a rivet gun. The player can use each weapon in a close-range melee attack, unlike in the first game, and is able to equip a weapon and a plasmid at the same time, which they can use in quick succession to destroy enemies. you take the role a earlier version of the big daddy as the alpha series named subject Delta, the story was amazing, the graphics look fasincated, gameplay was great, this game also inculdes a mulit-player option where you get to fight other players online and this time with plasmids, i give this game a 9.5 out of 10, i highly recommened that you should get this game also i can't wait to get Bioshock Infinite

reviewText:
Much better than Bioshock 1, I would say. The storyline is clearer and the difficulty is more managable. In Bioshock 1, what frustrated me the most was that I had to keep dying and respawning just to kill a mob, and I was almost always out of ammo every time. This was not the case in Bioshock 2. It also isn't as dull as Bioshock 1, having a larger variety of enemies, environments and weapons. It is also now more convenient to use Plasmids and Weapons as you can equip both at the same time on different hands.

Hacking machines also feels less time-consuming.

The bug where your customized controls and settings wouldn't save is also fixed from Bioshock 1.

The DLC, Minerva's Den, is also very worth the money. It gives a few chapters and hours of extra gameplay with a slightly different arsenal of weapons. I especially love the Ion Laser, which is more effective than the Machine Gun.

Rating: 7/10

So now one splicer can beat out the ♥♥♥♥ from YOU. Literally. When I played first Bioshock I always hated BD's because of their skill to ♥♥♥♥ me off so quickly. Bioshock 2 beaten the score. What is even worse than this copy pasting is the necessity of scavenging and using every ♥♥♥♥ing object to hide. You cannot save your resources for later use and when you really need them, nothing is in reach. Last thing for mention is the Questing. reviewText:
I don't think enough people give this game credit. All I heard was that this Bioshock was weak, lame, etc. However, it's pretty clear that it is NOT a true sequel to Bioshock, simply another story that takes place within the same location at a different time. There are small details connecting the two within the game but neither story has anything to really do with the other.

Gameplay was familiar so there was no learning curve but fighting Big Daddies and Big Sisters became a challenge. Still too many Plasmids to choose from and use, plus everytime you equip one, it seems to change which is binded to which key, which made utilizing them effectively a pain in the ♥♥♥.

Playing the perspective of a Big Daddy was very cool and certainly a different atmosphere from playing Bioshock. Controls are smooth, game looks nice, it feels different and familiar all at the same time. My only real gripe with the game is that it crashed as I was trying to finish collecting the ADAM samples to draw out Alexander and had to use the '-dx9' command to jury-rig the game so I could finish.

I don't think I have the heart to attempt playing the games again to get the other endings, since the Little Sisters are much too sweet to kill. Being called 'best daddy' even though I'm a chick was just too cute and heart warming.

reviewText: From a story standpoint, Bioshock 2 is definetly weaker than Bioshock 1. However, from a gameplay standpoint, I'd say that this game is superior in every way. Better hacking, more opportunities to get Adam (i.e you can gather 2 bodies with a little sister to get some extra Adam),Dual Wielding (THANK OUR LORD AND SAVIOR ANDREW RYAN FOR THAT DESIGN CHOICE), and, of course, you get to play as a Badass Big Daddy. It's pretty cool how you start off as an amnesiatic guy with nothing but a drill and end the game as a killing machine making other Big Daddies look like pushovers in comparison. Now, about the defence missions. These missions arent as bad as some people make them out to be. Mainly because the game gives you just enough gadgets to prepare yourself. At the start of the game, it may be a bit annoying, but as you go through, it'll become alot less so. If you dont want to do them, you dont have to. You can just skip the gathers by killing the Big Daddy, adopting the Lil sister and taking her to a vent and choose to save or harvest her. Like i said before, while the story is weaker than it's predecessor (its not terrible, just not as good), Bioshock 2 surpasses it in terms of gameplay. It took what the first game worked with, and improved every component of it. In my opinion, Bioshock 2 is the BEST game in the trilogy. 9/10\n\nNote: I forgot to mention this, but the game has the tendency to occasionally crash. If the game crashes on you at some point, I reccommend constant quick saving so you dont lose much progress.

reviewText: Compared to Bioshock 1 I found that BS2 is a fantastic sequel which fixes all the bad gameplay ideas from the first game and adds it's own flavor to things. The story is deep and twisted and you should play the first game before this to enjoy it to the fullest.\n\nGameplay: Moving/shooting is solid and weapons really do damage unlike in BS1. You have a lot of choices with weapon upgrades and plasmids (sort of magic in BS-world) and you can make your own character build" to some extent. You can use different approaches when it comes to encountering enemies i.e. hacking security cams to make the enemies trigger the alerts instead of you
date:
shooting through the corridors or confusing your enemies to fight each other with plasmids.

Story: Story is dark and gritty and mostly presented with audio recordings. This isn't necessarily the best way to tackle the storytelling but you will be rewarded with a lush backstory if you have the patience to listen.

Summary

Pros:
-Graphix still pretty
-Improved gun-/plasmidplay
-Story
-Atmosphere
-All the different options and upgrades

Cons:
-Story told mostly by audio recordings
-No one plays the multiplayer anymore
-I encountered some serious crashing during two last levels and lost 3 hours
worth of progress. Because of this I encourage everyone to quicksave/save
constantly to avoid such thing. Too bad they won't probably be fixing this major
problem anymore...

Overral a brilliant game that suffers some serious bugs (later in the game for me)."

reviewText:
I played this game at launch, and it was pretty bad. GFWL was a nightmare, there was constant crashing, multiplayer was a buggy mess, and the actual campaign was severely lacking. I probably would have given it an overall rating of 4.8/10. A slightly below average game.

When it was updated recently, I gave it another try. I do applaud 2K for releasing the massive patch so long after the game was released. For current owners, they got the Minerva's Den DLC for free, GFWL was removed, Steam achievements were added, several bugs were fixed, and multiplayer was much better. Still not perfect though. Lots of lag and no proper anti-cheat in multiplayer, and lots of crashing in single player.

Anyway, on to the main game. The biggest problem I had with the story was that it felt the exact same as the first one. The villain, Sofia Lamb supposedly had entirely different point of view than Andrew Ryan of the original game, but it didn't feel like that because the way she carried out her actions and the way she talked/presented herself was the exact same as Ryan. Some of the endings were a little cliche, the writing for Eleanor had some really cheesy and mediocre moments, and the overall story just didn't feel right. Like, it was all based around this relationship between Eleanor and you, a big daddy. And you're not even her actual father or anything haha. It was just strange. Cool idea, but I think it could have been written better.

I do think a few of the added moral choices were a great touch, how a few main characters fates were all dependent on you. Soundtrack was also fantastic. And while the multiplayer is completely unnecessary, when it worked, sometimes it was pretty fun. The whole background was kinda cool, how it all takes place when Rapture goes to ♥♥♥♥. But of course, there's a stupid levelling system tacked onto it which can kill interest quick. Had to grind for so long to get the last few achievements.

Gameplay wise, there was definitely an improvement. Instead of having all the different types of tonics, they were just grouped under one general selection. Dual wielding was great, and many of the weapons were a lot of fun to use. However, just like the first one, the movement is clunky, the FOV is awful and the guns still felt sluggish. Graphics are ugly for a 2010 game, and environments were practically identical to the original. Enemy variety was essentially the same, and the constant Big Sister fights were just annoyingly tedious and stupid.

I guess I'd give BioShock 2 a flat 6.0/10. It's a decent game. There are definitely improvements from the original, and a few great ideas. However, throughout the campaign, it just really felt like 2K was beating a dead horse. Get it on a sale.

As far as the Minerva's Den DLC goes, it gets universal praise everywhere I see it. I really didn't think it was that special to be honest. The story was decent and the pacing was good, but the gameplay just felt like more of the same. I'd give it 5.5/10, it's an above average add-on.

reviewText: Bioshock 2-An odd game indeed\n\nThe first bioshock was a milestone in game progression with story, setting, and enviorment. Bioshock was so unique because it was a different type of shooter with RPG elements. The story itself was movie quality writing and for that, it earned it's reputation, Bioshock 2 is like if you took Bioshock 1 and drop it in the dirt, it's the same game, but if you wipe it off, it's pretty fun. reviewText: Bioshock 2-An odd game indeed\n\nThe first bioshock was a milestone in game progression with story, setting, and enviorment. Bioshock was so unique because it was a different type of shooter with RPG elements. The story itself was movie quality writing and for that, it earned it's reputation, Bioshock 2 is like if you took Bioshock 1 and drop it in the dirt, it's the same game, but if you wipe it off, it's pretty fun. The story while not as astounding as the first, was still pretty good. The new characters are not as memorable as Andrew Ryan, but there are some nice editions. Missions and plasmids have been greatly updated. The game is without-a-doubt not as good as Bioshock, but it isn't bad. Infact, it's pretty good.

reviewText:
I am in love with Rapture, the art and style is truly exceptional. I could wander there for hours just to look at the small details in the environment.
The story IMO is not as good as the first one but I think it holds up well on it's own. The game has some welcome news as for example, Big Sisters and that you are able to dual wield weapons/plasmids which makes battles more fluid than in the first game. The graphics may be outdated but the audio is outstanding, all the buzzing of cameras, dripping water and footsteps echoing the halls really makes me immersed. I really like the music as well, a little pompous but I think it fits really well here.
The multiplayer portion is pretty unbalanced I think when it comes to team/match making system and plasmid/weapon combos. There are combos that are extremely OP compared to the weapons you start with. That makes me want to gain XP fast so that I can unlock new weapons to compete in any way. The MP maps are really nice, I was a little surprised that there were so many of them, this is first and foremost a single player game and a lot of different modes to play: free for all, capture the sister, ADAM grab etc.
All the achievements are transferred from the GFWL service and is a very welcome addition, even though I first bought it on GFWL.
I recommend this game wholeheartedly!

reviewText:
This game is more for those who played Bioshock 1 and didn't want it to end. It adds new stuff, of course, and it's easier to get ADAM. But generally, it's not much different from Bioshock 1. It's like Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel in terms of sequels. Other than multiplayer, it doesn't add anything new of substance ( multiplayer has terrible optimization and a small options menu, also it has permanent hot mic, you'd have to change steam settings to turn off mic). Although, it is fun after awhile.

P.S. If you change the settings of your gpu card to a low quality or to preformance instead of quality, it looks really ♥♥♥♥ and the textures spaz out constantly.

P.P.S. Like the first game, there are multiple endings that you get based on your morality. Also, killing unarmed enemies will not get you the bad ending. Of course, harvesting little sisters will. That is the only thing that affects the ending, like Bioshock 1.

reviewText:
I rate Bioshock 2, 3.5/5. Pretty good.

It is a fast, intense and extraordinarily violent (I really think it didn't have to be as violent as it was) but fairly short game full of atmosphere and excellent quotes, particularly from the esteemed character Doctor Lamb who, I believe, has some good ideas (not all of which are correct) and makes herself a villain by attempting to put those ideas into practice in entirely the wrong ways. It is less buggy than Bioshock 1 and has an interesting plot and a continual sense of urgency and excellent but often extremely busy, messy graphics.
